comments.body:
Overall suggestion: Matching the structure for `want` and `have` would make the map_obj_to_commands method much simpler. 

From your code, the `want` dict would always have the all the keys in it, even the ones with no value(i.e., `None`). 

If you follow the same logic for `have`, you can remove all the try-except blocks in map_obj_to_commands. Though redundant, but for the sake of readability, if you wish you can return `None` from the parse_* methods if no match is found. 

Have a look at [this](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/network/ios/ios_user.py#L352-L356)

@NilashishC  I have change the `try` `except` bit with the following. Not sure if that' s exaclty what you were suggesting but I see the code is more clear and like you said it follows the same structure as `have`

```
    server_have = have[0].get('server', None)
    source_int_have = have[0].get('source_int', None)
    acl_have = have[0].get('acl', None)
    logging_have = have[0].get('logging', None)
    auth_have = have[0].get('auth', None)
    auth_key_have = have[0].get('auth_key', None)
    key_id_have = have[0].get('key_id', None)
```
